description: From Middle English stinten, from Old English styntan (“to make blunt”) and *stintan (attested in āstintan (“to make dull, stint, assuage”)), from Proto-West Germanic *stuntijan, from Proto-Germanic *stuntijaną and Proto-Germanic *stintaną (“to make short”), probably influenced in some senses by cognate Old Norse *stynta, stytta (“to make short, shorten”).

entries.meaning: A period of time spent doing or being something; a spell.
examples: He had a stint in jail.

entries.meaning: Quantity or task assigned; proportion allotted.

verbs.description: stint (third-person singular simple present stints, present participle stinting, simple past and past participle stinted)

entries.meaning: (archaic, intransitive) To stop (an action); cease, desist.
examples: We maun have pain that never shall stint.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To stop speaking or talking (of a subject).

examples: The next party you throw, don't stint on the beer.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To restrain within certain limits; to bound; to restrict to a scant allowance.
examples: I shall not in the least go about to extenuate the Latitude of it: or to stint it only to the Produćtion of Weeds, of Thorns, Thisiles, and other the less useful Kinds of Plants

entries.meaning: To assign a certain task to (a person), upon the performance of which he/she is excused from further labour for that day or period; to stent.
(of mares) To impregnate successfully; to get with foal.
examples: The majority of maiden mares will become stinted while at work.

entries.meaning: Any of several very small wading birds in the genus Calidris. Types of sandpiper, such as the dunlin or the sanderling.
